citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Male Alaskan Klee-Kai (tag 2760, DOB 05/29/2016) has poor dental health. The dog has only one upper right cheek tooth
remaining and the entire surface of the tooth is coated in a buildup of grey-brown colored material. The gum has receded
away from the tooth, and the tooth is loose and moved easily when gently manipulated by the inspector. The lower right
cheek teeth are also coated in a buildup of grey-brown colored material and several of the teeth appear to be worn down
to approximately half their original size.
The dog has two upper left cheek teeth remaining and the entire surface of both teeth are coated in a buildup of grey-
brown colored material. One of the upper left teeth is loose and moved easily when gently manipulated by the inspector.
The gums directly above the teeth are dark red, appear swollen, and have receded away from the teeth.
The condition of this dog's teeth has not been identified by the facility, and no treatment has been provided or planned.
Female Schnauzer (tag 2369, DOB 05/07/2018) has poor dental health. The entire surface of the upper left and right
cheek teeth and nearly the entire surface of the upper left and right canine teeth are covered in a buildup of brown
material. The gums appear to have receded away from the upper left cheek teeth, and a grey colored substance is
located along the gum line of the upper left cheek teeth. The lower left cheek teeth are also coated in a buildup of brown
material. The upper right gums are slightly reddened. The condition of this dog's teeth has not been identified by the
facility, and no treatment has been provided or planned.
Poor dental health can cause pain and discomfort to the animal as well as lead to further health issues.
Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat injuries and illnesses. The licensee
must have these two dogs evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective
treatment plan. The licensee must ensure that all dogs receive adequate veterinary care at all times.
Correction date: By 5pm on January 14, 2026

A buildup of hair, cobwebs and organic material are located in several areas of the dog building. There is a significant
amount of hair hanging beneath the wire flooring of the majority of the dog enclosures. A buildup of feces and organic
material is located under the enclosures where the wall and floor meet. Along the back wall towards the center of the
building, there is a buildup of hair, dirt, debris, and rodent droppings on the floor. An additional buildup of dirt and debris is
also located on a tool cart, and a few rodent droppings are found on a table. There is a noticeable odor of ammonia
throughout the building. A total of 73 adult dogs and 69 puppies are housed in this building. A buildup of dirt, hair, and
debris can increase the risk of disease towards the dogs.
Surfaces within the housing facility that are not in contact with animals must be cleaned and sanitized when necessary.
The licensee must clean the floors, windows, table and cart and ensure that all surfaces in the building are kept clean in
order to reduce the risk of disease and odor of ammonia.
Correction date: January 19, 2026

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
At least three metal access doors used by the dogs to move between the indoor and outdoor sections of their enclosures
have a dark brown buildup of dirt on their surfaces. There are at least 10 dogs housed in these enclosures. Additionally, at
least half of the enclosures have a buildup of cobwebs and hair on the upper portions of their fencing, and the majority of
the whelping enclosures have tops that are coated in a buildup of cobwebs and hair. There are at least 40 adult dogs
housed in these enclosures and 60 puppies. The licensee stated that he believes the dog enclosures are sanitized every
2 months using ammonia. Failure to sanitize enclosures according to the requirements of the Animal Welfare Act can
allow for the buildup of organic material which could increase the risk of disease hazards.
Used primary enclosures and food and water bowls for dogs must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks and more
often if necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, waste, and disease hazards. Any detergent or disinfectant
used for sanitizing must be appropriate to reduce the risk of disease hazards towards the dogs. The license must ensure
primary enclosures, including the metal access doors, upper sections of fencing, and the tops of the whelping pens are
sanitized at least once every two weeks or more often if necessary to eliminate the buildup of dirt, hair, cobwebs and
disease-causing agents.
Correction date: The licensee was verbally instructed during the exit interview that beginning January 12, 2026 and
onward that sanitization must take place at least every two weeks.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Numerous discarded items are lying on the ground around the building housing the dogs. The items include cardboard
boxes, sections of wire flooring, dewormer bottles, plastic transport crates, animal bones, metal items, and wood boards.
Trash and discarded items could attract disease carrying pests such as insects and rodents to the area housing the dogs.
Premises must be kept free of accumulations of trash, junk, waste products, and discarded matter. The licensee must
remove all the discarded items located around the exterior of the dog building and ensure the area remains free of trash,
junk, and unused items at all times.
Correction date: January 19, 2026

During the inspection, two dogs were identified as having poor dental health. The dental plan documented in the facility's
Program of Veterinary Care states there will be a yearly check of the teeth, dental toys will be provided, and if high
prevalence of dental disease is noted then preventative measures will be taken. The inspector asked the licensee what
the preventative measures are that are to be taken but the licensee did not know. A dental plan that is ineffective at
maintaining clean and healthy teeth could result in poor dental health which can cause pain and discomfort to the animals
as well as lead to further health issues.
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that contains a preventative care and treatment plan to
maintain clean and healthy teeth. The licensee must consult with the Attending Veterinarian to develop and document in
writing an effective plan to maintain clean and healthy teeth.
Correction date: January 26, 2026

The Attending Veterinarian conducted the annual exam of the dogs in September 2025, but there are no medical records
documenting the results of the exams. Failure to record the results of medical exams may interfere with the ability to
provide appropriate care to an animal should an injury or illness have been identified during the exam.
Dealers must keep copies of medical records for dogs and the records must include dates and the findings/results of all
screening, routine, or other required or recommended tests or examinations. The licensee see must ensure that the
results of the yearly exams are documented on a medical record and a copy of these records are kept, maintained, and
available during the inspection.
Correction date: The licensee was verbally instructed during the exit interview that all exam results are to be documented
beginning January 12, 2026 and onward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Male Alaskan Klee-Kai (tag 2760, DOB 05/29/2016) has poor dental health. The dog has only one upper right cheek tooth

The dog has two upper left cheek teeth remaining and the entire surface of both teeth are coated in a buildup of grey-

The gums directly above the teeth are dark red, appear swollen, and have receded away from the teeth.  
The condition of this dog's teeth has not been identified by the facility, and no treatment has been provided or planned.  
 
Female Schnauzer (tag 2369, DOB 05/07/2018) has poor dental health. The entire surface of the upper left and right

Each dealer shall use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat injuries and illnesses. The licensee 
must have these two dogs evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective 
treatment plan. The licensee must ensure that all dogs receive adequate veterinary care at all times.
